risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Sarah Bernardi1 and Amy Sugar2
Registered Social Worker & Masters of Social Work, Veterinary Social Work, Ontario Veterinary College and Health Sciences Centre, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON, Canada
Veterinarian and APLB Certified Pet Loss and Bereavement Counselor, Toronto, ON, Canada

sect2.title: 16.1 Introduction

blockquote.para: If a child is old enough to love, (s)he is old enough to grieve

sect2.para: The tremendous role veterinary technicians play in end‐of‐life (EOL) care and euthanasia can be more challenging when families with children are impacted by the loss of a pet. Children suffer from grief, even if they express it differently from adults. The loss of a family pet can be particularly heartbreaking for children, who may be experiencing death for the first time. A child’s experience interacting with the veterinary team may be minimal, and thus it is especially important to ensure a positive experience for future veterinary visits. EOL events often trigger intense emotions and behaviors. Many parents will experience increased anxiety about EOL care, particularly euthanasia decisions and appointments, as they are uncertain how to communicate about this difficult subject and how their child will cope.

blockquote.para: In a 2001 analysis of 450 calls to a pet loss and education support line, nearly 25% of callers indicated that their primary reason for contacting the hotline was to request information on how to talk with children about the illness, death, or euthanasia of a family pet [ch0029-c16-bib-0001, p. 183].

sect2.para: Parents and caregivers will often look to the technician for support and guidance with pet loss and grief. It is important to remember that the technician is not acting as a trained therapist or a close friend. Their role is to show compassion, explain and answer questions about the pet’s condition and care, allow space and time for expression of emotions, and provide reputable, reliable resources for the entire family unit. Supporting the family unit through grief is not only good for the soul but also for the business of the practice. Even if a technician does not have a direct role in supporting the family, having knowledge of how to engage with children and families at EOL is valuable for guiding team members in these interactions. These extra steps in care and consideration reflect positively on veterinary practices, both for the experience of the clients and the well‐being of staff.

This chapter details how technicians can engage with families and children during their beloved companion’s EOL care. Specifically, guidance will be provided for appropriate language, phrases, and communication considerations when working with children; how technicians and their teams can feel confident and prepared when including children in euthanasia; and how to provide effective resources and support around children’s memorialization and grief process. Veterinary technicians often form close bonds with their patients. They can continue to honor this bond through EOL planning, euthanasia, and post‐euthanasia by supporting the children that those pets have loved so deeply.

sect2.title: 16.2 The Role of Technicians in Supporting Families with Children

blockquote.para: We communicate our feelings without having to say a word. He is never too busy when I just need someone with whom I can share my thoughts. He is the most loyal friend, and the strength of our bond is immeasurable.

sect2.para: It is important to recognize the special bond and the meaningful role a pet plays in a child’s life (Figure 16.1). The death of a beloved companion animal of any species is a unique and significant loss and should be treated as such, sincerely offering compassion and support for the child’s grief (Pro Tip 16.1).

Many technicians will be born animal lovers and recall vividly the love and loss of their childhood pet. It may spark emotions and strong beliefs in how to handle or not handle this loss, depending on their own experience as a child. This bias needs to be recognized and perhaps revisited and supported if it is impacting the technician’s work.

In the past, it was not an unusual practice to shield children from the reality of pet loss to protect or spare them from the pain. While this approach often comes from a place of good intentions, it can be harmful. It is recommended to communicate with children about pet loss openly and directly. Guidance for this is included in subsequent sections, including language tailored to different age groups. Most parents feel great anxiety anticipating their children’s reaction to the loss of a pet. Parents are dealing with their own sadness, and this is compounded by the uncertainty of how to explain the pet’s death to their children (Pro Tip 16.2). Families may become overwhelmed and can project their feelings negatively onto veterinarians, technicians, and staff.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 16.2 Supporting Parents of Grieving Children
sidebar.para: Often parents are extremely anxious about their child’s grief response, and this compounds their own grief and sadness. Having parent resources and children’s pet loss books in the practice to give or loan out to parents to read before euthanasia is thoughtful and appreciated.

sect2.para: Clients may already be having open conversations about death with their children. Technicians can be present to provide reassurance, resources, and a sympathetic ear. Parents can readily access a plethora of information about grief with a quick internet search. The challenge that can arise with this accessibility is that it may be difficult for parents to discern reputable information from misguided advice. The knowledge, skill set, and personal insight that the veterinary team can provide will help parents navigate their child’s emotions and questions.

The technician needs to communicate effectively to inquire if the parent would like help or support for the entire family unit. Parents may not realize that the veterinary team can provide pet loss support and resources, so it is important that they are always offered. The EOL care team can facilitate discussions to identify the family’s questions and concerns and encourage parents to consider how involved they’d like their children to be early in the process of planning. Involving children in EOL planning and the EOL transition helps acknowledge the importance of their bond with their pets. Technicians can help parents consider age‐appropriate ways for children to be involved as much as the children and parents would like them to be. Veterinary practices may consider having front desk staff inquire about who makes up the family unit, but they can also ask more generally if there are any children important in this animal’s life during client registration. This allows for child‐inclusive care and support to be offered throughout the practice's relationship with clients.

sect2.title: 16.3 Children’s Perceptions and Age‐Specific Advice
sect2.para: Every child is unique, and each case can vary based on a child’s personality, parental guidance, relationship with the pet, prior experience with loss, culture, and religious beliefs, as well as many other factors. The following chart offers general guidelines for children's perception of death based on chronological age. Another important factor is a child’s developmental age, which refers to their level of physical, emotional, cognitive, and social development. This may differ from their actual age in years.Table 16.1 provides a tool for veterinary technicians to understand how children can participate in EOL procedures, but it can also be a useful aid for parents.

sect2.title: 16.4 Talking to Children About Death and Loss of a Pet
sect2.para: Veterinary technicians should only engage in discussions of death and pet loss with children after they receive permission from their parents. The technician can directly acknowledge the children during appointments and ensure they feel safe asking questions. When discussing death with a child, the technician will need to be aware of modifying language and details based on the age and interest of the child. It is best to let the child’s questions guide the conversation as often children will require honest, simple, and short answers. Give a small amount of simple information and they will ask for more detail if they desire. Remember that children are often different from adults when it comes to the subject of death. They are more curious and open‐minded. This is positive, in that young children are often interested and grateful for the answers to their questions. It gives veterinary teams the opportunity to provide truthful and helpful answers about EOL and death.

sect3.title: 16.4.1 Use Simple and Direct Language
sect3.para: Veterinary technicians should use honest, simple terminology and speak slowly. Try to answer what the child is asking specifically; most times younger children are not interested in too much detailch0029-c16-bib-0002. Often young children worry about their beloved pet being hungry or lonely, so they need to hear that this is not the case. For very young children, it may be helpful to liken pet death to something they may have experienced such as a plant or flower dying.

When communicating with children, technicians may feel concerned that they do not have all the right answers or feel they need to be perfect in their explanations. Rest assured that most children will respond positively if their questions are addressed in a way that shows care, validation, and support. Technicians do not need to fill silence with words, sitting in silence can demonstrate comfort with the emotions surrounding grief. Let those feelings exist! Body language and vocal tone are also important in communicating with children (Communication Corner 16.1).

sect3.title: 16.4.2 Validate Feelings
sect3.para: Children need adults to confirm that it's all right to feel sad and to cry. When ignored, children may suffer more from feeling isolated than from the actual death itself and may feel alone in their griefch0029-c16-bib-0002. Validating their feelings and being present with them in the moment is important. The technician can advise staff and parents to let children know it is okay to be sad, angry, or even numb. There will also be times when a child may not react as expected, and that is acceptable as well. They should not feel pressure to display feelings that are not present. In general, open and honest communication with children is the best way (Pro Tip 16.3).

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 16.1 Body Language and Vocal Tone
sidebar.para: Conveying a message is not just done with words. Body language and voice tone are a significant factor in how a message is received.

listitem.para: Maintain soft eye contact: Follow the child’s lead on how comfortable they are with eye contact.

Keep open body language: Open body language is a relaxed posture, with arms indicating friendliness and warmth, closed body language is tense, arms folded indicating a person is “closed off” (see Figure 16.3).
Getting on the child’s physical level: Don’t tower over them, especially when talking to them.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 16.3 Naming and Validating Emotions
sidebar.para: Young children may not know the words to describe what they feel. The technician can assist and model by recognizing that emotion, naming that emotion, and validating that emotion. For example, “You may be feeling angry, it doesn’t seem fair. I would be angry too.” Linking the emotion to a physical state often helps. For example, “My tummy hurts also when I feel sad or scared” or “It can feel like your heart hurts when you are so sad.”

sect3.para: Adults often feel death is a difficult subject to approach with children. For many people, the first instinct is to protect children from feeling sad or try to cheer them up. Realistically, when children experience the loss or impending loss of a pet, they need the time and space to allow them to feel sad and encourage expression of emotion. Telling or relaying to a child “don't feel bad or sad or mad” sends a confusing message, not a comforting one. By doing so, children are being told not to feel what they are truly feeling. This can close the door to further healthy dialogue because a child may feel they have to pretend or hide their feelings as that is what is expected of them. When children (especially those over the age of five) are left out of discussions, they feel unworthy of trust and this can be distressing. A child may feel they have to find answers on their own, which can lead to misinformation from unreliable sources (friends/internet) and may cause more distress.

It is important to make sure children know they are not responsible for the pet’s illness or death. Children will often blame themselves even if there is no real basis for this. A child may need to be assured by parents that nothing they said or thought would cause this to happen to the pet. A complex situation can arise when the death/accident is caused by the child. For example, the child left the backyard gate open, and the dog ran out and got hit by a car. This again would be a situation best handled by the parent and professional mental health provider. This is a teachable moment, not one to be hidden. It would be the parents’ responsibility to help the child work through the guilt and regret. If the technician is asked for advice on the matter, it is important in this case to focus on the fact it was an accident and mistakes do happen. The technician can assist by empowering the child and the family unit with knowledge and understanding to prevent this from happening again and offering grief resources.

sect3.title: 16.4.3 Be Patient and Nonjudgmental
sect3.para: Veterinary technicians will need to exercise patience as younger children may ask the same question over and over. With children, it is best to listen, answer the question directly, and then pause to listen to their cues of what they need next. A child’s behavior may seem inappropriate to the situation. There are many reasons for this so the veterinary team must try to be nonjudgmental during this emotionally driven time.

The content in this chapter offers guidance; however, technicians will need to follow their best judgment and learn from experience and consultation with colleagues. Every child will grieve in a unique way as feelings of grief are different for everyone. For instance, teens might feel embarrassed or ashamed of their grief. The technician can create a safe space and normalize these expressions.Case Study 16.1 offers an example of the complexities of grief and family dynamics.

sidebar.title: Case Study 16.1 Mrs. Kim and Jingles
sidebar.para: Mrs. Kim enters her regular veterinary practice to euthanize her cat of 20 years, Jingles. The veterinary technician Sarah asks if Mrs. Kim would like other family members involved. Mrs. Kim shares that her husband does not want to be present, and her four‐year‐old daughter Lane has never liked or interacted with Jingles. In fact, Lane often acts jealous of Mrs. Kim’s attention to Jingles. Sarah learns that Mrs. Kim and her husband have both agreed not to discuss euthanasia with Lane, as they feel she won’t be impacted by the loss.

Sarah uses this opportunity to share with Mrs. Kim why it might be helpful to share their decision with Lane and offers child‐specific resources for review, but Mrs. Kim declines. Sarah accepts this response and tells Mrs. Kim that if she changes her mind about the resources, she is welcome to reach out.

A few weeks later, Sarah receives a phone call from Mrs. Kim who shares that Lane began acting out at home shortly after Jingles’ euthanasia and she wonders if it has something to do with the loss. Specifically, she is worried that her own sadness is impacting Lane. Sarah acknowledges her concerns. Listening empathically, she reminds Mrs. Kim that the practice has child‐based grief and loss resources, including a chart that offers age‐specific guidance for children’s grief. With Mrs. Kim’s permission, Sarah has a member of the reception team email the resources to her.

During a follow‐up call with Mrs. Kim, Sarah learns that Lane had been confused and upset, witnessing her mother’s sadness. Lane thought it was her fault because she sometimes wished Jingles was gone. In learning this, Mrs. Kim was able to provide reassurance that nothing Lane thought or said caused Jingles’s death and that she was not mad at Lane. The family began reading children’s books from the resource list and created a book of pictures about Jingles as a memorial activity.

para.emphasis: Can you identify important ways Sarah supported the entire family unit?

sect3.title: 16.4.4 Avoid Euphemisms
sect3.para: In general, adults tend to lean on euphemisms. A euphemism refers to using words and phrases that discuss sensitive or unpleasant subjects in a more tactful manner. For example, saying“passed away” instead of “died.” There is a time and place for euphemisms, but young children may take them literally, which can create confusion around death and dying.

Avoid euphemisms such as “Fluffy has been put to sleep” or “Fluffy has gone away.” This communication can lead to confusion and fear surrounding sleep or others “going away” on a trip. Death needs to be explained in a simple way such as “Fluffy has died which means he does not breathe, eat or play anymore. Fluffy is not sick or hurting.”

sect3.title: 16.4.5 Avoid Lying
sect3.para: Encourage parents not to fabricate stories such as“Fluffy went to live on a farm” or “Fluffy ran away.” The notion of a pet running away will be distressing to the child. They will wonder why the pet ran away, where it is, and when it may come back. This notion may lead to unmerited guilt with a child believing the pet went away due to something they did, thought, or said. It is also questionable whether children truly believe these fibs even at a young age. A child will often have negative feelings and anxiety if they sense adults, who they are supposed to trust, are lying to them. Children will feel a lack of trust as they grow up once they realize that this was not true and contemplate “what else their parents and veterinarian lied about” (see Case Study 16.2).

Unfortunately, parents may sometimes try to enlist the help of the veterinary team in authenticating a lie about what has really happened to the pet. It is important that technicians avoid becoming part of the lie, and do not feel pressure to say or do something they feel is unethical. The technician may provide a gentle reminder that although honest communication might seem more painful for the child in the present, it is best in the long term. Lying to the child, even with good intentions, can lead to mistrust and anger with parents and the veterinary profession later in life. Although it is not the technician’s role to tell parents what to say and what not to say to their children, they can encourage parents to tell the truth and provide resources to support them in a sensitive, age‐appropriate manner.

sidebar.title: Case Study 16.2 Amit
sidebar.para: Amit has started his summer student job at the veterinary practice where his family has been a long‐term client. Amit is aspiring to apply to become a technician after graduating high school. One day while Amit is working, he looks up his family’s medical records where he learns that both of his beloved kittens were euthanized years ago when he was a young child. His parents had told him the kittens went back to live on the farm with the rest of the litter. They assured him the kittens were happier on the farm and then quickly replaced them with two new kittens.

Amit is shocked and confused by the discovery and confronts the veterinary team (whom he has greatly trusted and respected over the years). The team was unaware that Amit’s parents had lied to him about the euthanasia and were unsure of how to handle the situation. Amit angrily confronts his parents and immediately quits his job for the summer.

para.emphasis: Why do you think Amit reacted this way? How could the veterinary team support Amit going forward?
If time could be rewound to before the kittens were euthanized, how could the veterinary team have helped the parents prepare for honest and open communication with Amit?

sect3.title: 16.4.6 Avoid Blame
sect3.para: Technicians will keep in mind that language should be appropriate for young listeners and discussions should avoid blaming others or relaying disturbing details about the physical state of the pet. In some circumstances, the technician may need to gently remind the parents not to blame the veterinarian. Placing blame on others will not appease the child and may lead to negative feelings or anxiety around veterinarians and other health professionals. It is all right to express to a child that veterinary professionals are also animal lovers and are very sad to lose a patient.

sect3.title: 16.4.7 Spiritual and Religious Considerations
sect3.para: The family’s religious and cultural beliefs will need to be respected throughout the discussion with the children when providing explanations and with word choices. This is especially important during discussions of the afterdeath and afterlife (e.g. questions regarding heaven). It is best to leave these types of discussions solely to the parent.Communication Corner 16.2 offers examples of how technicians may respond to these questions.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 16.2 Responding to Questions About Death

para.emphasis: “Why does my pet have to die?”

listitem.para: “Fluffy’s body has a disease that is really powerful, and we can't make it go away. Important parts of his body don't work anymore, and we can’t help him stay alive. Because we love him so much, we need to do the kind thing and help him die peacefully without any more pain.”

para.emphasis: “Why couldn’t the vet save my pet?”

listitem.para: “We are all animal lovers and try to do everything possible to save your pet so they can enjoy life with your family. Veterinarians and veterinary technicians can do many things to help sick or injured animals but sometimes an animal cannot be saved, no matter how much we want to or how hard we try.”

para.emphasis: “Is death like sleeping?”

listitem.para: “No, death is nothing like sleeping. Everyone needs sleep to rest while they are alive. Living creatures wake up after a rest. Once an animal dies, they will not come back to life. When a pet dies their body does not work anymore. The pet does not eat, sleep or breathe again. Their heart will stop beating and it will not start again.”

sidebar.para: If asked directly about opinions and beliefs regarding spiritual and religious questions, technicians can reflect the question back to the child:

para.emphasis: “Do you think my dog is in heaven now?”

listitem.para: “That’s a great question, what do you think?”

para.emphasis: “What is heaven like? What will Fluffy do in heaven?”

listitem.para: “That is a good question! I have wondered about that too. What do you think Fluffy will do in heaven? Maybe you can draw a picture of what you think it is like there and talk to mom/dad about it.”

sect3.title: 16.4.8 Parent/Caregiver Resources for Children of All Ages
sect3.para: It is important to ensure the veterinary practice has a list of resources for parents with children and teens (Table 16.2). Parents may be hesitant to ask or may not realize that resources will be helpful. Resource lists can be sent out via email or given on a printed handout that is updated as needed. Some resources on pet loss and grief can be presented on the practice website so parents or teens can easily be directed to that area for information.

It is essential to remember that sometimes grief in a child or teen is very serious and long‐lasting. That individual may need more support and professional counseling, which is beyond the scope of a technician’s role. The EOL team can encourage them to seek help from a professional mental health provider or physician in these cases (Pro Tip 16.4).

sidebar.para: Veterinary practices should have a prepared, accessible, and updated resource list, including crisis lines and emergency services dedicated to kids and teens in their area.

sect2.title: 16.5 Supporting Children Through Diagnosis and Treatment of a Pet’s Serious Illness
sect2.para: A study analyzing calls placed to a pet loss support line identified that many callers struggled with communicating their pets’ serious illnesses to their children, specifically at times of diagnosis or when the animal became visibly sickch0029-c16-bib-0003. Technicians may have to work with parents struggling to have these conversations with their children. If parents are seeking guidance, technicians can encourage them that setting a foundation for truthful discussions can benefit everyone, especially the child/teen, as they navigate their pet’s illness. This will allow everyone in the family to contribute to care and decision‐making in a meaningful way (see Case Study 16.3).

sidebar.title: Case Study 16.3 Mrs. Jose, Christine, and Shaggy
sidebar.para: Mrs. Jose is struggling with the decision of whether to inform her preteen daughter Christine about their beloved dog Shaggy’s cancer diagnosis. Mrs. Jose anticipates Christine will struggle with the news, as Shaggy has been a part of their family for most of Christine’s life and they share a deep bond. Mrs. Jose decides not to disclose the diagnosis to Christine at this time. Instead, she plans to take Shaggy for weekly chemotherapy treatments in secret, intending to inform Christine only if Shaggy’s health significantly deteriorates. Upon learning this, the technician, Kelly, feels conflicted and recognizes this secrecy could lead to greater challenges. After considering the situation and discussing it with the vet team, Kelly decides to have a thoughtful conversation with Mrs. Jose at their next appointment.

Mrs. Jose arrives for the next appointment, and after review of the care plan Kelly revisits their prior conversation, “I wanted to revisit what you shared about your daughter at our previous appointment. You mentioned you decided not to tell her about Shaggy’s cancer.” Kelly pauses a few moments to let Mrs. Jose process this statement and respond. Mrs. Jose confirms that she still does not want to tell Christine, as she is worried about her potential response and how it will impact her mental well‐being. Kelly shows empathy. “It is so hard to share a cancer diagnosis with children. I remember you mentioned that your daughter is very bonded with Shaggy.” Mrs. Jose agrees and further explains how helpful and responsible Christine is when caring for Shaggy.

Kelly listens and validates this before sharing, “I wanted to take a moment and discuss this. In my experience, although this news is going to be heartbreaking to your daughter, it will be more devastating if Shaggy dies, and Christine doesn’t understand why or finds out Shaggy’s cancer was hidden from her. You said Christine is so responsible and helpful when she cares for Shaggy. She might appreciate having an active role in helping to manage Shaggy’s cancer care.” Mrs. Jose agrees that Christine would appreciate being a part of this process and will plan to tell her about the diagnosis. Kelly shares, “We are here to support you and can answer questions or concerns Christine may have about Shaggy’s condition. She is more than welcome to come to appointments and get familiar with the team and hospital.” Kelly sends Mrs. Jose home with resources and the clinical summary.

para.emphasis: How might anticipatory grief be affecting Mrs. Jose’s decision not to tell her daughter about Shaggy’s diagnosis and chemotherapy?
If Mrs. Jose decided not to share the diagnosis with Christine, how might the technician respond instead?

sect2.para: Veterinary technicians should be aware of how anticipatory grief can influence how families communicate about and cope with their pet’s diagnosis and treatment. More information about anticipatory grief can be found in Chapter 14.

sect2.title: 16.6 Involvement of Children Through Euthanasia
sect2.para: In many households, even young children share a significant role in caring for a family pet. For example, one study found that “75% of 8‐ to 10‐year‐olds had sole or shared responsibility for pet care, and 92% felt that caring for their pets was an ‘important’ or ‘very important’ part of their relationship with the animal”ch0029-c16-bib-0001. The child should continue the responsibility of care through EOL, euthanasia, and aftercare and it is important for the veterinary team to recognize this sense of responsibility. Children should feel they are part of the care team. Their bond with the pet needs to continue to be fostered throughout EOL. Although it is imperative for a child to feel part of the discussions and decision‐making, it is also necessary that they do not feel the full burden and responsibility for the final decision. The technician can assist parents in providing information and options on how children can be involved before, during, and after euthanasia.

sect3.title: 16.6.1 Preparing the Family for Euthanasia
sect3.para: Prior knowledge of what to expect at the time of euthanasia may help ease anxiety in both the parents and children. Preparation is also helpful to reduce stress for the patient and the veterinary team. Discussions of euthanasia should be held privately with the parents first, which will allow them the opportunity to voice concerns about their children and provide information about their ages and the level of involvement the parents feel would be appropriate. The veterinary team should review the entire process of euthanasia with the parents in detail, including possible physiological changes that may be observed (seeChapter 11). If parents are not educated about what could happen, they may become upset with what their children are witnessing. Once the parents are aware of what will or could happen at each stage, they can decide about which part, if any, they feel is suitable for their child to observe (see Pro Tip 16.5). It is also important to make it clear that anyone can change their mind at any time. If they initially want their child to be present throughout and decide to change their minds midway, then they are welcome to do so.

It is also helpful to send written information or provide access to digital resources in advance that explain the euthanasia procedure, what to expect, and how to prepare. Parents may be emotional, distracted, or still in a state of disbelief during discussions, so it is best for them to have access to information they can revisit at a quiet moment. Whenever possible, aftercare and keepsake options should be provided ahead of the scheduled euthanasia. This will enable time for all family members to make thoughtful choices beforehand as they may not be thinking clearly or be unable to decide what they want on the day of the euthanasia. Often families express regret later for not getting a keepsake such as a clay paw print or change their mind about the return of cremated remains. With parental consent, children can be included in aftercare decisions suitable for their age and developmental stage. Parents can be encouraged to review the information from aftercare providers in advance. This may be helpful when they explain the process to their children.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 16.5 Involving Children in Saying Goodbye
sidebar.para: If a child is too young or chooses not to be present, they can still be involved. For example, a young child could oversee preparing a “comfort” or “goodbye bag” to accompany the pet to the euthanasia appointment and decide on the contents, such as a favorite toy, special blanket, picture, or card created by the child.

sect3.para: It is recommended that all family members are given up‐to‐date information about when euthanasia is going to occur. Parents may try to spare a child’s feelings and euthanize the pet while the child is at school or lie and say the pet died in their sleep. The veterinary team can suggest to parents that the child may eventually find out the truth and these deceptions can lead to mistrust of both parents and health professionals.

Many people don’t realize that there are several steps during a euthanasia appointment that family members can be involved in, even if they choose not to be present during the actual euthanasia procedure. The veterinary team can discuss some ways children can be involved without being present during the procedure such as having time to say goodbye at home before parents take the pet to be euthanized, coming to the hospital and staying in a separate room with a caregiver during the procedure, staying until the pet is sedated and saying goodbye before the moment of euthanasia, or coming in for visitation after the pet is euthanized.

The veterinary practice should have information available about home euthanasia and whether this is offered by the practice itself or a mobile service. This option can be advantageous when children are involved. It may allow for the pet and child to feel the comfort of their home space and offer more opportunities for members of the family to be in multiple spaces if needed throughout the process. As with any resource, the family can decide what feels right for them.

The technician should explain that children (and family members) can change their minds and leave at any point during the procedure. A trusted caregiver should come to the procedure in case the child wants to leave. Also, coloring sheets/books and other child‐safe activities in the room are helpful to give a child something to occupy their attention during that time.

sect3.title: 16.6.2 Explaining Euthanasia to Children
sect3.para: Parents may request assistance in explaining euthanasia to their children. As a first step to approaching this conversation, technicians should gauge the family’s understanding and experience with euthanasia. Technicians can ask parents about what has already been discussed with the child and the language they have been using to communicate with them. This allows an opportunity for technicians to share that language should be truthful but modified according to age, developmental, and emotional level. Technicians might find it helpful to break down this explanation of euthanasia by answering “why, what, and how” questions.

sect3.title: 16.6.2.1 Why Is This Happening?
sect3.para: Veterinary technicians can recommend relaying to the child that the pet is suffering from a disease, illness, or injury and that this is causing the pet’s body to die. Euthanasia will end any discomfort or suffering by helping the pet to die. It is out of love that we choose to end the pet’s suffering through a peaceful, gentle death.

sect3.title: 16.6.2.2 What Does It Mean?
sect3.para: Sometimes children benefit from a definition of euthanasia and feel empowered that they understand this big word; it can be helpful to share that euthanasia is a Greek word that literally means “good death.”

sect3.title: 16.6.2.3 How Does It Happen?
sect3.para: The parents should ensure the child understands that this specific injection is given only by a veterinarian to an animal that is dying. This will help avoid creating a fear of vaccines or other injections related to this conversation or experiencech0029-c16-bib-0004. It is suggested to avoid referring to the euthanasia drug as “medicine,” as children may become fearful of taking their own medicine when they are sick ch0029-c16-bib-0004. Further guidance for describing euthanasia to children may be found in Communication Corner 16.3.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 16.3 Describing Euthanasia to Children

para.emphasis: “How will the vet help Fluffy die?”

listitem.para: “Fluffy will get an injection of a very strong drug to stop his heart and it should not be painful. This is a specific drug that is only given by a veterinarian to animals who are dying.”

para.emphasis: “Will it hurt when Fluffy is euthanized?”

listitem.para: “No, the vet will help Fluffy die so he can stop hurting. This is called euthanasia which means very easy and peaceful death. Euthanasia makes Fluffy’s heart stop beating, and he will stop breathing. His body will die, and he won’t feel pain anymore.”

para.emphasis: “Is Fluffy afraid to die?”

listitem.para: “What Fluffy knows right now is that his family loves him so much and is taking care of him.”

para.emphasis: “Why are Fluffy’s eyes open if he is dead? Can he see us?”

listitem.para: “Animals often die with their eyes open, that’s completely normal, but Fluffy cannot see or hear anything now.”

sect3.title: 16.6.3 The Presence of Children During Euthanasia
sect3.para: Veterinary teams will often encounter parents seeking advice on whether it is appropriate or advisable for children to be present for euthanasia procedures. There is no simple right or wrong, yes or no response. Ultimately, it is up to the parents to decide, especially for young children, since they know their child and their family dynamics best. Technicians may still offer insight and resources to parents as they make this decision (Table 16.3). EOL care teams should be familiar with clinic policy and the comfort level of the veterinarian doing the procedure before making any suggestions to the family ch0029-c16-bib-0005. If there is a lack of comfort or clinic policies preventing the involvement of children, this should be addressed on an organizational level. The existence of these barriers will hinder the provision of the best possible compassionate EOL care to the clinic’s clients. Technicians with the desire to elevate their practice’s standard of EOL care can be sources of information, inspiration, and change within their workplaces as they seek training and share their support.

The decision for children to be present and their level of involvement can encompass many elements, such as past experience with loss, behavior of the child, family dynamics, level of understanding and awareness, and chronological and emotional agech0029-c16-bib-0005. Also, the parent's own feelings about witnessing the euthanasia and having the child present during the procedure play a crucial part in the decision‐making process. Children will sense how their parents feel so if the parents or other adults are not comfortable with the child being present, the child may not get the support they need ch0029-c16-bib-0005.

Table 16.3
Benefits and challenges of children‐present euthanasia.

The parents may also feel that having their children included may prevent them from being as present and connected with their pet, so they are less able to honor their own bond at this important time. Very young children may require a lot of attention to keep them safe (from needles, bites, scratches, etc.) and to reduce noise, stimulation, and stress for the pet being euthanized. This can sometimes interfere with the creation of a calm and supportive environment for the pet and others attending the euthanasia. Parents should be encouraged to bring a second caregiver in case a child changes their mind at the last minute, needs to leave the procedure, or is disruptive to the parent, veterinary team, or pet.

It is important to remember that parents can set the most beneficial example regarding healthy grieving. Negative feelings projected from adults, a child’s questions that remain unanswered or ignored, and other less‐than‐ideal situations during euthanasia may lead to a very difficult grief process for the family unit.

The presence of children during euthanasia is a deeply personal decision that varies by age and individual family dynamics. Each age group presents unique challenges and benefits, requiring thoughtful consideration and tailored approaches from the technician. In the authors’ opinion, consideration of children present in euthanasia can be loosely examined within the following chronological age ranges:

sect3.title: 16.6.3.1 Children Under the Age of Five
sect3.para: It is generally advisable that children this young should not be present during euthanasia. The added stress of managing an infant during the appointment may take a parent’s focus away from grieving at the moment. An upset infant or toddler may disrupt the flow of an appointment for veterinary staff and grieving parents. Although it is all right for young children to see sadness expressed by their parents, uncontrolled outbursts or sobbing will be very distressing. It is best, if possible, for parents to attend euthanasia and leave a very young child with a trusted caretaker.

sect3.title: 16.6.3.2 Middle to Late Childhood (6–13 Years)
sect3.para: Most school‐age children are eager to ask questions and relay their honest opinions. This age is often very curious, intelligent, and resilient. They may be very candid and straightforward in their communication. If the child is old enough to answer whether they wish to be present, they should be asked. Often, they have had their pet as long as they can remember, and this may be their first experience with death. Children of this age range may benefit from the opportunity to have their grief validated, observe their parents mourn, and have space to ask questions and express concerns surrounding death. Safe and age‐appropriate ways to participate in a pet’s EOL journey can be encouraged, such as deciding on what toy or blanket to bring for them, drawing or coloring pictures, or reading a poem or story to the pet.

sect3.title: 16.6.3.3 Teens and Young Adults (14–21 Years)
sect3.para: Often this age group feels that the pet is their own and may resent the parents for “giving up on the pet.” This group sees the world in a very idealistic way and may have great difficulty with the decision to euthanize. It is important to take the time and patience to explain the medical information to them and answer their questions. They need to feel they are being seen and heard and are important members of the decision‐making process. This age group may feel they share the responsibility of the pet’s care, so it offers them a chance to participate in this caring decision and say goodbye. It is also a good opportunity for them to hear from the veterinarian and technician about why this is an acceptable ethical decision.

University‐age young adults also warrant special consideration. Although technically not children anymore, this age group often has a very strong bond with their pets; they have shared many life stages with this beloved childhood companion. These young adults should be afforded the opportunity to be present at the euthanasia, whether this is in‐person or accommodated virtually. Missing this chance to say goodbye may lead to increased feelings of guilt and impact their grieving process.

sect3.title: 16.6.4 Preparing the Veterinary Team for Children‐Present Euthanasia
sect3.para: Veterinary technicians can initiate and encourage meaningful dialogue with other team members to set protocols for children‐present euthanasia. It needs to be determined if the veterinarians are willing and comfortable when explaining, answering questions, and discussing EOL care with children. If this is an issue, it is the editors’ opinion that it is the responsibility of the veterinary team to seek training to become comfortable so that best practice compassionate euthanasia may be offered to include children. If a veterinarian requests assistance in this area, a technician with training may assume the role of communicator during EOL discussions and euthanasia. This should be discussed and arranged in advance to ensure everyone is in agreement on the protocol and how best to prepare. It is valuable to identify and leverage different team members’ strengths, such as those with more interest, aptitude, and training in EOL care and communication.

Technicians can set the tone by sharing with the family that this is a safe space for sharing and expressing feelings, reminding them that everyone grieves in their own way (seePro Tip 16.6). There are some scenarios where a child’s behavior cannot be managed, and they become a disruption to the procedure. In these cases, the safety of the patient, family, and staff takes priority, and a parent will need to accompany the child out of the exam room or practice. The technician can also consider the physical space available for families. Many practices will not have the space for a designated comfort room. An exam room can be transformed into a safer and more comfortable space by adding thoughtful and creative adjustments (Table 16.4).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 16.6 Focus on the Pet in Challenging Situations
sidebar.para: In situations where a child or teen’s reaction to euthanasia is creating tension with other participants in the procedure, a technician may find it helpful to redirect the family’s attention to the pet. Specifically, redirect the family to the common goal, which is supporting and caring for the animal at their EOL. For example, “We are all here to help Fluffy have a peaceful passing, Fluffy knows his family is with him, so let’s focus on Fluffy right now.”

sect3.title: 16.6.4.1 EOL Comfort Kits for Children
sect3.para: It is helpful to have an “EOL Comfort Kit for Children” for euthanasia appointments (seeFigures 16.4 and 16.5). Staff should remember to check and refill, ensuring the kit is fully stocked and ready when needed.

listitem.para: Travel tissue packages: Each family member can have their own package, which ensures their comfort during the procedure and after they leave the practice.
Sanitizing gentle wipes: Important for safe and quick cleanups, especially with kids.
Bottles of water : Clients might be in the exam room for longer periods of time, so having water ensures they can stay hydrated and provides an extra level of care.
Special bags: When removing and returning collars/leashes or gifting children’s books, it is important to have a nice‐quality bag for the family to put these items.
Small keepsake bags: The family may wish to keep a clipping of fur; it is thoughtful to place this in a bag that is secure and can be used as a memorial item.
Coloring sheets, stickers, and crayons: Adding coloring sheets that are age appropriate can help to keep children occupied and engaged during EOL appointments.
Children’s story/activity books: Books written about pet loss for children are very helpful when supporting families through loss and grief.

Special picture frames (cardboard/no glass insert for safety): The child can draw a picture of the pet and insert it in the provided frame, or the veterinary practice can print out a picture of the pet and have it ready for the family.

Sturdy card/paper for personalized paw and nose prints: Include a variety of cardstock for children to choose and decide if they wish an ink/paint paw or nose print.

Printed list of grief resources: Having a general pet loss resource handout is important. If there is a ready list for everyone, any family member can discreetly take it and have it for reference later if needed.

sect2.title: 16.7 Preparing for the Unexpected
sect2.para: What happens when an unexpected situation arises and thoughtful EOL preparation is not possible? The technician will encounter these stressful circumstances and needs to be aware that euthanasia may not transpire in an ideal manner. However, there is some good news. Even though veterinary teams cannot prepare for every unexpected situation, they can still be prepared to handle them. Having gained the knowledge and practiced the communication techniques presented here and throughout this book, technicians have the resources to manage the unexpected.Case Study 16.4 provides an example of a technician’s compassionate handling of a difficult situation.

sidebar.title: Case Study 16.4 Ms. Singh and Ginger
sidebar.para: Late afternoon at the veterinary practice, an urgent walk‐in arrives. A mother, Ms. Singh, with her two young children, a six‐year‐old and an eight‐year‐old, rushes in with their family cat, Ginger, who is in medical distress. Ms. Singh is not a current client of the practice. After Ginger is assessed, the vet, Dr. Wilson shares with Ms. Singh that the prognosis is grave and reviews the options, but ultimately Ms. Singh decides on humane euthanasia, as her funds are severely limited. Dr. Wilson recommends euthanasia be done as soon as possible to alleviate Ginger’s suffering and discomfort.

Dr. Wilson brings the family and the cat into the comfort room. Ms. Singh tries to explain the situation to her kids, and the kids become inconsolable. The children scream and cry at both Dr. Wilson and their mom. They don’t understand why Ginger can’t come home. The children hold Ginger in their arms, blocking any access to the cat.

While Ms. Singh is trying to calm down the kids, Dr. Wilson steps out of the room, feeling overwhelmed, and discusses the situation with the technician, Kayla. Dr. Wilson shares that she doesn’t have much experience with child‐present euthanasia but knows that Kayla does and asks for her support. Kayla suggests that she can join the appointment and help gain control of the room. They walk back into the room together and Dr. Wilson introduces Kayla to the family, explaining that she will be helping. Kayla shares with Ms. Singh that she has brought some comfort items for Ginger that the kids can help pick out. Ms. Singh seems open to this idea and Kayla brings over the “EOL Comfort Kit for Children.”

Kayla sits on the floor in front of the children and shows them the EOL Comfort Kit. She asks them which blanket they think the cat would like to stay warm and comfortable, the kids choose a blanket, she agrees that it is the perfect choice and then helps them wrap Ginger in it. Kayla then asks the children to have a seat on the couch so she can lay the cat in their lap.

While Kayla engages with the children, Dr. Wilson takes Ms. Singh aside in the room and informs her about what to expect during the procedure. Dr. Wilson asks Ms. Singh if the family would like to be present during the euthanasia or after for visitation, and Ms. Singh says she would like the family to stay for the procedure.

Ms. Singh rejoins the kids on the couch, and Kayla tells them, “I am going to stay with you the whole time to make sure Ginger stays comfy and to answer any of your questions. You can ask me whatever you would like.” She asks the kids some questions, “What are Ginger’s favorite toys and treats?”

Dr. Wilson is now able to access the cat for the procedure and the euthanasia is very peaceful. After the procedure, Kayla says “We will leave the room now. Take as much time as you want to spend with Ginger. When you are ready, just turn the door sign to signal that you want us to come check‐in.”

Kayla returns when the family signals they are ready and asks if the children would like any keepsakes. The children decide they wish to have a fur keepsake. Kayla also lets Ms. Singh know that there is a resource list on the practice website should she wish to obtain more information on memorial ideas and grief resources. Ms. Singh expressed her gratitude for the extra time and care Kayla offered her children.

para.emphasis: How was the technician’s presence helpful in this situation?
How did the technician’s preparation help her manage this unexpected and tension‐filled situation?

sect2.title: 16.8 Supporting Children’s Grief Through Memorialization
sect2.para: An important part of supporting a child’s healthy grieving process includes engaging in support activities, reading books on pet loss, and participating in memorials for the pet. The veterinary practice can offer pet loss support resources for children in a variety of ways: gifting them to the family, displaying them in the practice for purchase, or having a dedicated page on the practice website. Parents who may be struggling through their own grief will often be very grateful that they don't have to source appropriate resources themselves.

Reading children’s stories about pet loss can help children understand death, encourage expression of feelings, and provide comfort through grief (seeTable 16.2 for resource suggestions). Families can engage in support activities together, such as working through activity books designed for children coping with pet loss. Art therapy is very helpful for people of all ages, especially for young children who can use this method to express feelings that they can’t verbalize or don’t fully understand. These family activities can also give parents insight into a child's thoughts. Older children and teens can benefit from activities such as scrapbooking, journaling, and creating memorials. Parents can model healthy coping strategies by participating in these projects as well. Examples of memorial ideas for families and children are provided in Table 16.5.

After euthanasia, personalized keepsakes for the family are often very valued and supportive during grief. End‐of‐life (EOL) care teams can consider a variety of keepsakes to offer children such as a small clipping of fur in a special bag, nose or paw print impression on cardstock, and memorial picture frames. Ideally, each child who wishes for a keepsake should receive one if possible. Veterinary teams should always obtain permission from the family before creating a keepsake such as a paw print impression or fur clipping. Another way to involve children in creating keepsakes is to allow them to brush the pet’s fur and add it to the keepsake bag themselves (seeFigure 16.6).

sect2.para: It is helpful for the technician to have a printout, digital copy, or area on the clinic website with some suggestions for memorials. Children should be involved in these memorial activities as it is helpful in the grief journey for the entire family (seePro Tip 16.7).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 16.7 Include Children on Sympathy Cards
sidebar.para: When sending families sympathy cards, EOL care teams should consider having a variety of cards, some of which are more appealing to children. All family members' names should appear on the card, so children feel included and respected in their grief.

sect2.para: Providing pet loss support resources and memorial items is helpful for families as it demonstrates the validity of the child’s grief. Additionally, this tangibly reflects the value placed on the human–animal bond, showing the level of compassion the veterinary team feels for every pet patient and their family. It is important for the veterinary team to provide these afterlife gestures of compassion. Technicians who feel passionate about this may take the lead in establishing these practices. Clients feel reassured when they are properly supported through EOL. They will often remain loyal to the veterinary practice and contribute to its reputation surrounding compassionate EOL care.

sect2.title: 16.9 Considerations for Getting a New Pet
sect2.para: Another common question parents will ask the technician is when to consider adopting a new pet. Although there is no exact right or wrong timing, this decision should not be made hastily as it is ideal to wait until everyone in the family feels ready. Many parents struggle deeply watching their children experience sadness and grief. Although this is difficult, grief is something that the child needs to experience. Children need to take the time to feel sad and parents should not try to resolve feelings of loss by rushing in to adopt a new petch0029-c16-bib-0006. Adopting a new pet too quickly may not give the child enough opportunity to grieve, especially for children over the age of five. This may lead to unresolved emotions and challenges with future experiences of loss. It also signals to the child that their feelings of grief are not important, valid, or acceptable.

Children can vary greatly when considering the possibility of adopting a new pet. Some will say they want a new pet right away, while other children may say they don't want to have another pet in the home. Children need to be reassured that it is ok to develop a bond with another pet and it is also ok to want to wait before even thinking about adopting again. Veterinary technicians can encourage respect for all family members' decisions about potential future pets and make sure everyone is aware of not succumbing to the pressure of adoption too soon. Technicians can recommend that parents ensure a child understands that a new pet may be very different and is not meant to replace an old pet. If they do not understand this, they may feel anyone who dies can be replaced, even them. Introducing a new pet before everyone is ready may cause feelings of anger, resentment, or guilt and a feeling of being disloyal to their pet that has died. When the entire family unit is ready, involving the child as much as possible in the selection process and preparations for a new pet would be advisable.

listitem.para: Children form deep and unique bonds with their pets. The loss and grief they feel needs to be recognized and respected. The technician plays a supporting role for parents looking for advice about their child’s role in EOL care for the pet.
The technician should become familiar with child‐sensitive words/phrases and body language to ensure communications with children surrounding EOL are clear and comforting.

Children’s understanding of death and their ability to cope with grief are influenced by factors such as chronological and developmental age, culture and religion, prior experience with loss and grief, and parental guidance surrounding these issues.

It is imperative to prepare a list of age‐appropriate resources for parents with children and teens. Ideally, resources should be offered prior to the day of the euthanasia so parents can be prepared for questions about death and emotions surrounding grief.

Children old enough to make a choice about involvement in EOL and euthanasia should be given the opportunity to do so. The family unit should be provided with options to decide when/how they wish to participate before, during, or after euthanasia.

The clinic and veterinary team should be prepared for children of various ages being involved in euthanasia with EOL comfort kits for children, family resources, aftercare information, ideas for support activities, personalized keepsakes, and memorial selections to ensure the EOL experience is as positive as possible for every family member.
16.1 Mrs. Kim and Jingles
16.2 Amit
16.3 Mrs. Jose, Christine, and Shaggy
16.4 Ms. Singh and Ginger

Sarah recognized the opportunity to discuss and offer resources around children and pet‐related grief. When Mrs. Kim declined this support, Sarah did not push her, rather she accepted this without judgment and offered the opportunity to revisit the conversation. When Mrs. Kim reached out again, Sarah listened carefully and without judgment. She once again offered support in the form of grief resources. The family was able to talk about their loss together using these resources.

Amit may be struggling with a lot of feelings, thoughts, and emotions as a result of this discovery. To support Amit going forward, the veterinary team could consider reaching out to check in, validate his feelings, and offer resources for grief and mental health. It is not the veterinary team’s role to become involved in family dynamics; do not offer to facilitate conversations between the family.

The veterinary team should not feel pressured to authenticate a lie on behalf of the parents. Ultimately it is always the parents’ decision on how they choose to communicate with their children. However, the veterinary team can emphasize the importance of open and honest communication; fabricating a lie or story will not rid a child of their pain from loss, it only delays it and potentially complicates grief.

Remember that it is not the technician’s responsibility to put a label on the client’s behaviors or emotions. However, it is valuable to contemplate and observe how experiences such as anticipatory grief or caregiver burden may be impacting Mrs. Jose’s decision not to tell Christine. It may help inform the technician about how to effectively communicate and support their clients.

In this scenario the technician should remember not to push or try to convince Mrs. Jose to tell her daughter. The technician can communicate in a similar way to the initial scenario, “I want to remind you that we are here to support you and can answer questions or concerns Christine may have about Shaggy’s condition. She is more than welcome to come to appointments and get familiar with the team and hospital if you do choose to tell her.” The technician can still offer Mrs. Jose resources that she can refer to.
The technician collaborated with the vet, became an ally for the mom, and supported the children while ensuring patient care and comfort remained the priority.

Having tangible resources that could be ready, stocked, and on hand for use of child‐involved euthanasia. Specifically, the EOL Comfort Kit for Children and a list of grief resources and memorialization ideas were helpful.
